title: The Art of Doing Science and Engineering
author: Richard W Hamming

notes.content:
Clearly I need to dig into the Fourier series, it can do so many tricks!

I'm aware that the Fourier series breaks a single signal down into a bunch of sine waves. This implies that you can choose the number of sine waves to compose, thus giving increased or decreased resolution for the result.

What else can I use for this? Can I create images from Fourier series?
Then I could easily send a thumbnail by only sending the most significant terms of the series?

Is this going from design of the filter to the details of the filter?

So what's the angular frequency? and what's that w symbol?

Why is f both frequency and rotations?

I still can't tell what eigenfunction and transfer function actually mean

What are terminal and interval values?
I need to do further reading on the "noiseless coding theorem of Shannon" cause I don't quite get this.

Is this related to the bayesian theory of surprise described at http://ilab.usc.edu/surprise/ ?

How far does the proposed definition, for example Shannon's definition of information, agree with the original concepts you had, and how far does it differ?
Press Enter to edit this note
This is one of my favorite books ever! I strongly recommend you read this book!

This is where I first discover the print edition I own is rather different from the digital copy I found.
"Training is how to do it." Does that mean coder bootcamps are a perfectly fine idea? Does this already imply the idea of blue collar coding? Would white collar coding be the "what, when, and why to do things" ?
